CVD Risk Factors and Guidelines for CVD Prevention

Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) remain the leading cause of death globally. It includes a spectrum of conditions characterized by the disease of the heart and blood vessels. Common types of CVDs are coronary heart disease, cerebrovascular disease, peripheral artery disease, congenital heart disease, and rheumatic heart disease. Identifiable risk factors such as smoking, high blood pressure, abnormal blood lipid levels, diabetes mellitus, sedentary lifestyle, and obesity contribute significantly to CVD. According to the European Society of Cardiology (ESC), CVD risk prediction and prevention are critical aspects, considering the age-related effect on risk profile. 

Risk Stratification for CVD

CVD risk stratification allows healthcare providers to identify individuals with relatively high CVD risk and undertake relevant interventions to reduce these risks. Risk stratification involves various factors and algorithms to assess an individual's risk profile accurately. Some of these risk factors include age, sex (male, female), blood pressure (systolic and diastolic values), total cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, smoking status (current smoker, former smoker, never smoked), and diabetes (fasting plasma glucose, HbA1c). The presence of multiple risk factors increases the risk more than each factor alone. Hence, using a combination of risk factors allows for a comprehensive assessment. 

Based on the risk factors mentioned above, CVD risk stratification can be performed using age- and sex-specific risk calculators or algorithms. A frequently used tool is the NICE Guideline which provides guidance on assessing an individual's risk of cardiovascular disease and recommending interventions accordingly. The NICE CVD risk stratification algorithm takes several parameters into account and provides a percentage risk of experiencing a CVD event over a specific period (usually five to ten years). NICE guidelines on the management of raised blood cholesterol and cardiovascular risk in adults

NICE issued updated recommendations for the management of raised blood cholesterol (including high cholesterol and dyslipidaemia) and associated cardiovascular risk in adults (NICE, 2022). Key guiding principles have been developed to ensure consistency and clarity in clinical management in both the primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease (CV).

Further guidance can be found from NICE (2022) on preventing cardiovascular disease (NICE, 2022) and reducing risk of cardiovascular disease among patients with multimorbidity (NICE, 2022).

Definitions

Cardiovascular disease (CVD)

A range of diseases including atheroma (fatty deposits) in the blood vessels such as coronary artery disease leading to myocardial infarction or stroke.

Risk factors

The following factors increase the risk of developing cardiovascular disease including myocardial infarction, stroke or peripheral vascular disease:

Atheroma – this develops in the artery walls with risk increasing as the thickness of the fatty deposit increases (coronary artery disease and stroke risk).

Hypertension (high blood pressure – this occurs when systolic blood pressure (the top number) is higher than 140 mmHg or diastolic blood pressure (the bottom number) is higher than 90 mmHg). An average reading between these numbers is considered normal, with lower values considered safe.

Dyslipidaemia – defined as the abnormal amount/types of lipids or fat in the blood. An increased concentration of low density lipoprotein (LDL) and/or a decreased concentration of high density lipoprotein (HDL) increases the risk of atherosclerosis.

Diabetes mellitus

A chronic condition in which the body does not respond normally to insulin, or does not produce enough insulin (when the pancreas fails to produce enough).

Smoking

Any combustible substance from a cigarette or similar product contains approximately 20,000 chemicals, some of which are toxic. They have been shown to increase cardiovascular risk factors independently of other factors. It can also slow the recovery after a cardiovascular event.

Applying the guidelines

These guidelines are in place to support national strategies on the prevention of CVD through risk factor modification, including the management of raised blood cholesterol. They have been produced to improve and reduce inequalities in CV care. These guidelines will be revised in the future.

The guidelines have broad application and are relevant to any medical practitioner involved in CVD clinical practice. They include healthcare professionals involved in risk assessment (primary care, community and primary care trust settings), secondary prevention after a cardiovascular event including secondary care.

There are four guiding principles for the application of these guidelines: (i) they are informed by the evidence base; (ii) they are based on expert opinion; (iii) they are informed by policy; (iv) they are iterative guidelines; as more evidence becomes available and clinical practice changes, these guidelines will likely be revised.

Introduction

A large proportion of adults in England do not meet national guidelines for managing cardiovascular (CV) disease (CVD) risk. The UK's most recent CV strategy1 recommends that, by 2017, half of all adults live in areas with low levels of CV risk. To achieve this, effective implementation of national evidence-based guidelines2, 34 is essential.

In England, the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) has published guidance for health professionals (HCPs) for assessing CV risk, CVD prevention and population approaches to CVD.5 This guidance outlines risk factors with evidence-based targets for population and individual-level interventions.

Public guidelines

The NICE CV risk assessment guidance6 (incorporating NICE evidence review 33)5 and the NICE CVD prevention guidance7 (incorporating NICE evidence review 38)8 are available to the public to inform the public and HCPs about managing risk and preventing CVD.

Strengths and limitations of the public guidelines

Public guidelines are most relevant for identifying health risks in people at low to moderate CVD risk at population level. People with a history of or risk factors for CVD should refer to the individual, clinical prevention guidelines (refer to HCPs).

Individual, clinical intervention guidelines

The Individual Clinical Practice Guidelines for CV risk assessment and management5 and for the prevention of cardiovascular disease (PVDC)7 (both in NICE Evidence Review 33 and NICE Evidence Review 38, respectively) are aimed at improving CV risk for individuals. The main population targets are:

- Blood pressure (BP) of 140/90 mmHg or higher in men and 130/80 mmHg or higher in women: reducing BP in men with levels at or above 140/90 mmHg, or in women with levels at or above 130/80 mmHg, to 130/85 mmHg

- Total cholesterol of 5.2 mmol/L or higher or low HDL-cholesterol (HDL-C) of 1.0 mmol/L or lower

- Smoking: smokers should stop smoking and avoid exposure to secondhand smoke.9

- Physical inactivity: at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity activity per week, as well as two sessions of muscle-strengthening exercises.

- Interventions based on diabetic status: for diabetics with CV risk: 10% or greater: reducing alcohol intake; smoking; increasing physical activity (if not contraindicated); drug therapies
